channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Author Correction: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy
item.dc:title: Author Correction: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy

item.title: Bitter taste TAS2R14 activation by intracellular tastants and cholesterol
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07569-9

Bitter taste TAS2R14 activation by intracellular tastants and cholesterol
item.dc:title: Bitter taste TAS2R14 activation by intracellular tastants and cholesterol

Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07549-z

Author Correction: Large-scale plasma proteomics comparisons through genetics and disease associations
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Large-scale plasma proteomics comparisons through genetics and disease associations

item.title: Legionella effector LnaB is a phosphoryl-AMPylase that impairs phosphosignalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07573-z

Legionella effector LnaB is a phosphoryl-AMPylase that impairs phosphosignalling
item.dc:title: Legionella effector LnaB is a phosphoryl-AMPylase that impairs phosphosignalling

item.title: Laser-powered bullets reveal surprising metal hardness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01514-6

Micro-ballistics research has shown metals hardening as they are heated, under extreme strain rates.
item.dc:title: Laser-powered bullets reveal surprising metal hardness
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Fentanyl addiction: the brain pathways behind the opioid crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01541-3

How two neural pathways contribute to the deadly opioid’s addictive nature, and why babies are suing the South Korean government.
item.dc:title: Fentanyl addiction: the brain pathways behind the opioid crisis
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Greek soldiers prove that ancient armour was combat-worthy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01402-z

A Mycenean bronze suit did not hamper movement of modern-day warriors performing fighting manoeuvres.
item.dc:title: Greek soldiers prove that ancient armour was combat-worthy

item.title: Mapping model units to visual neurons reveals population code for social behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07451-8

A deep neural network with ‘knockout training’ is used to model sensorimotor transformations and neural perturbations of male Drosophila melanogaster during visually guided social behaviour and provides predictions and insights into relationships between stimuli, neurons and behaviour.
item.dc:title: Mapping model units to visual neurons reveals population code for social behaviour
item.dc:creator: Benjamin R. Cowley
Adam J. Calhoun
Nivedita Rangarajan
Elise Ireland
Maxwell H. Turner
Jonathan W. Pillow
Mala Murthy

item.title: The solar dynamo begins near the surface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07315-1

Simple analytic estimates and detailed numerical calculations show that the solar dynamo begins near the surface, rather than at the much-deeper tachocline.
item.dc:title: The solar dynamo begins near the surface
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey M. Vasil
Daniel Lecoanet
Kyle Augustson
Keaton J. Burns
Jeffrey S. Oishi
Benjamin P. Brown
Nicholas Brummell
Keith Julien

item.title: Life-cycle-coupled evolution of mitosis in close relatives of animals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07430-z

We analyse cell division in ichthyosporeans and find that multinucleated life cycles favour the evolution of closed mitosis, in which the cell constructs a spindle within an intact nucleus.
item.dc:title: Life-cycle-coupled evolution of mitosis in close relatives of animals
item.dc:creator: Hiral Shah
Marine Olivetta
Chandni Bhickta
Paolo Ronchi
Monika Trupinić
Eelco C. Tromer
Iva M. Tolić
Yannick Schwab
Omaya Dudin
Gautam Dey

item.title: Natural proteome diversity links aneuploidy tolerance to protein turnover
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07442-9

Proteomic data from natural isolates of Saccharomyces cerevisiae provide insight into how these cells tolerate aneuploidy (an imbalance in the number of chromosomes), and reveal differences between lab-engineered aneuploids and diverse natural yeasts.
item.dc:title: Natural proteome diversity links aneuploidy tolerance to protein turnover
item.dc:creator: Julia Muenzner
Pauline Trébulle
Federica Agostini

Markus Ralser

item.title: Covalent targeted radioligands potentiate radionuclide therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07461-6

Radiopharmaceuticals engineered with click chemistry to selectively bind to tumour-specific proteins can be used to successfully target tumour cells, boosting the pharmacokinetics of radionuclide therapy and improving tumour regression.
item.dc:title: Covalent targeted radioligands potentiate radionuclide therapy
item.dc:creator: Xi-Yang Cui

item.title: Transcranial volumetric imaging using a conformal ultrasound patch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07381-5

A conformal ultrasound patch can be used for hands-free volumetric imaging and continuous monitoring of cerebral blood flow
item.dc:title: Transcranial volumetric imaging using a conformal ultrasound patch
item.dc:creator: Sai Zhou

item.title: Lense–Thirring precession after a supermassive black hole disrupts a star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07433-w

The accretion disk from a star tidally disrupted by a supermassive black hole undergoes Lense–Thirring precession with strong, quasi-periodic X-ray flux and temperature modulations.
item.dc:title: Lense–Thirring precession after a supermassive black hole disrupts a star
item.dc:creator: Dheeraj R. Pasham
Michal Zajaček
C. J. Nixon
Eric R. Coughlin

Bożena Czerny

Muryel Guolo
Yukta Ajay
Michael Loewenstein

item.title: Distinct µ-opioid ensembles trigger positive and negative fentanyl reinforcement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07440-x

Experiments using fentanyl treatment of mice show that µ-opioid receptors mediate positive reinforcement in the ventral tegmental area and negative reinforcement in central amygdala, thereby identifying the circuits that lead to opioid addiction.
item.dc:title: Distinct µ-opioid ensembles trigger positive and negative fentanyl reinforcement
item.dc:creator: Fabrice Chaudun
Laurena Python
Yu Liu
Agnes Hiver
Jennifer Cand
Brigitte L. Kieffer
Emmanuel Valjent
Christian Lüscher

item.title: Adhesive anti-fibrotic interfaces on diverse organs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07426-9

A study shows that implants with an adhesive implant–tissue interface mitigate the formation of a fibrous capsule when attached to various organs in mice, rats and pigs.
item.dc:title: Adhesive anti-fibrotic interfaces on diverse organs
item.dc:creator: Jingjing Wu
Jue Deng
Georgios Theocharidis
Tiffany L. Sarrafian
Leigh G. Griffiths
Roderick T. Bronson
Aristidis Veves
Jianzhu Chen
Hyunwoo Yuk
Xuanhe Zhao

item.title: Osmosensor-mediated control of Ca<sup>2+</sup> spiking in pollen germination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07445-6

Screening in Escherichia coli and biochemical experiments show that in Arabidopsis thaliana, OSCA2.1 and OSCA2.2 function as plant sensors of hypo-osmolarity, utilize Ca2+ oscillations as second messengers and have crucial roles in pollen germination.
item.dc:title: Osmosensor-mediated control of Ca<sup>2+</sup> spiking in pollen germination

item.title: Porous isoreticular non-metal organic frameworks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07353-9

The use of computational crystal-structure prediction has enabled the targeted assembly of frameworks of porous organic ammonium halide salts that have many of the qualities of metal–organic frameworks despite containing no metal.
item.dc:title: Porous isoreticular non-metal organic frameworks
item.dc:creator: Megan O’Shaughnessy
Joseph Glover
Roohollah Hafizi
Mounib Barhi
Rob Clowes
Samantha Y. Chong
Stephen P. Argent
Graeme M. Day
Andrew I. Cooper

item.title: Capturing electron-driven chiral dynamics in UV-excited molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07415-y

Time-resolved photoelectron circular dichroism with a temporal resolution of 2.9 fs is used to track the ultrafast electron dynamics following ultraviolet excitation of neutral chiral molecules, which generate chiral currents that exhibit periodic rotation direction reversal.
item.dc:title: Capturing electron-driven chiral dynamics in UV-excited molecules
item.dc:creator: Vincent Wanie
Etienne Bloch
Erik P. Månsson
Lorenzo Colaizzi

item.title: Structural insights into the cross-exon to cross-intron spliceosome switch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07458-1

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of cross-exon pre-B and B-like complexes contribute new insights into the molecular mechanisms that mediate the switch from a cross-exon to a cross-intron organized spliceosome.
item.dc:title: Structural insights into the cross-exon to cross-intron spliceosome switch
item.dc:creator: Zhenwei Zhang
Vinay Kumar
Olexandr Dybkov
Cindy L. Will
Jiayun Zhong
Sebastian E. J. Ludwig
Henning Urlaub
Berthold Kastner
Holger Stark
Reinhard Lührmann

item.title: A whole-slide foundation model for digital pathology from real-world data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07441-w

Prov-GigaPath, a whole-slide pathology foundation model pretrained on a large dataset containing around 1.3 billion pathology images, attains state-of-the-art performance in cancer classification and pathomics tasks.
item.dc:title: A whole-slide foundation model for digital pathology from real-world data
item.dc:creator: Hanwen Xu
Naoto Usuyama

item.title: Imaging surface structure and premelting of ice Ih with atomic resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07427-8

Atomic-resolution imaging of the surface structure of hexagonal water ice is achieved using cryogenic atomic force microscopy, providing a molecular perspective on the origin and mechanism of of ice premelting.
item.dc:title: Imaging surface structure and premelting of ice Ih with atomic resolution
item.dc:creator: Jiani Hong
Ye Tian
Tiancheng Liang
Xinmeng Liu

item.title: Acquisition of epithelial plasticity in human chronic liver disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07465-2

Single-cell RNA sequencing and 3D imaging have revealed the cellular changes and structural reorganization that occur during the progression of human chronic liver disease and as the liver attempts to regenerate.
item.dc:title: Acquisition of epithelial plasticity in human chronic liver disease
item.dc:creator: Christopher Gribben
Vasileios Galanakis

item.title: Observation of a promethium complex in solution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07267-6

Stable chelation of the 147Pm radionuclide in aqueous solution by the newly synthesized organic diglycolamide ligand is demonstrated and the resulting complex studied, showing accelerated shortening of bonds at the beginning of the lanthanide series.
item.dc:title: Observation of a promethium complex in solution
item.dc:creator: Darren M. Driscoll
Frankie D. White
Subhamay Pramanik

Alexander S. Ivanov

item.title: Metals strengthen with increasing temperature at extreme strain rates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07420-1

Microballistic impact testing at strain rates greater than 106 s−1 shows that pure metals, including copper, gold and titanium, become stronger with increasing temperature.
item.dc:title: Metals strengthen with increasing temperature at extreme strain rates
item.dc:creator: Ian Dowding
Christopher A. Schuh

item.title: Monolithic three-dimensional tier-by-tier integration via van der Waals lamination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07406-z

We develop a low-temperature, damage-free process using van der Waals lamination to integrate multiple circuit tiers into a monolithic three-dimensional device, incorporating unique multi-tier functionality and resolving legacy issues with the layering technology.
item.dc:title: Monolithic three-dimensional tier-by-tier integration via van der Waals lamination
item.dc:creator: Donglin Lu
Yang Chen

item.title: Electric recycling of Portland cement at scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07338-8

Recovered cement paste can be reclinkered if used as a partial substitute for the lime–dolomite flux used in steel recycling, which can reduce waste and carbon emissions.
item.dc:title: Electric recycling of Portland cement at scale
item.dc:creator: Cyrille F. Dunant
Shiju Joseph
Rohit Prajapati
Julian M. Allwood

item.title: Selective haematological cancer eradication with preserved haematopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07456-3

An antibody–drug conjugate that targets the pan-haematopoietic marker CD45 combined with transplanted stem cells engineered to be shielded from it can eradicate leukaemic cells while preserving haematopoiesis.
item.dc:title: Selective haematological cancer eradication with preserved haematopoiesis
item.dc:creator: Simon Garaudé
Romina Marone
Rosalba Lepore
Anna Devaux

Lukas T. Jeker

item.title: Kainate receptor channel opening and gating mechanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07475-0

Structures of the kainate receptor GluK2 with and without concanavilin A and BPAM344 show how these ligands modulate channel activity and reveal the molecular basis of kainate receptor gating.
item.dc:title: Kainate receptor channel opening and gating mechanism
item.dc:creator: Shanti Pal Gangwar
Maria V. Yelshanskaya
Kirill D. Nadezhdin
Laura Y. Yen
Thomas P. Newton
Muhammed Aktolun
Maria G. Kurnikova
Alexander I. Sobolevsky

item.title: Molecular mechanism of choline and ethanolamine transport in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07444-7

Structural analysis of the human choline and ethanolamine transporters FLVCR1 and FLVCR2 clarifies the mechanisms of transport, the conformational dynamics of these proteins and the disease-associated mutations that interfere with these processes.
item.dc:title: Molecular mechanism of choline and ethanolamine transport in humans
item.dc:creator: Keiken Ri
Tsai-Hsuan Weng

Schara Safarian

item.title: Strain-invariant stretchable radio-frequency electronics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07383-3

Stretchable radio-frequency electronics based on a dielectro-elastic elastomer is demonstrated to be capable of completely maintaining operating frequencies unaffected by strain and shows superior electrical, mechanical and thermal properties compared with conventional stretchable substrate materials.
item.dc:title: Strain-invariant stretchable radio-frequency electronics
item.dc:creator: Sun Hong Kim
Abdul Basir
Raudel Avila
Jaeman Lim
Seong Woo Hong
Geonoh Choe
Joo Hwan Shin

Yei Hwan Jung

item.title: Combined cement and steel recycling could cut CO<sub>2</sub> emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01359-z

Cement can be reused by including it as a component of steel recycling. This opens the way to an industrial partnership that improves the use of materials and lowers carbon emissions — but only if waste resources are well managed.
item.dc:title: Combined cement and steel recycling could cut CO<sub>2</sub> emissions
item.dc:creator: Sabbie A. Miller

item.title: Neural pathways for reward and relief promote fentanyl addiction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01361-5

Neuroscientists find that two distinct neural pathways are responsible for the addictive properties of the opioid fentanyl: one mediates reward, the other promotes the seeking of relief from symptoms of withdrawal.
item.dc:title: Neural pathways for reward and relief promote fentanyl addiction
item.dc:creator: Markus Heilig
Michele Petrella

item.title: Instability could explain the Sun’s curious cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01357-1

A phenomenon that affects the magnetic fields of rotating bodies could be involved in recurring changes in the Sun’s behaviour, which are related to a periodic flipping of its field. The proposal is a fresh take on this strange effect.
item.dc:title: Instability could explain the Sun’s curious cycle
item.dc:creator: Ellen Zweibel

item.title: Guidelines for academics aim to lessen ethical pitfalls in generative-AI use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01543-1

Researchers warn against normalizing the use of AI without safeguarding against risks.
item.dc:title: Guidelines for academics aim to lessen ethical pitfalls in generative-AI use
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: AlphaFold3 — why did Nature publish it without its code?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01463-0

Criticism of our decision to publish AlphaFold3 raises important questions. We welcome readers’ views.
item.dc:title: AlphaFold3 — why did Nature publish it without its code?

item.title: Bizarre bacteria defy textbooks by writing new genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01477-8

Bacterial defensive systems scramble the standard workflow of life.
item.dc:title: Bizarre bacteria defy textbooks by writing new genes
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Can mathematicians help to solve social-justice problems?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01494-7

Researchers discuss the triumphs and trials of using their craft to tackle society’s greatest challenges.
item.dc:title: Can mathematicians help to solve social-justice problems?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Crowell

item.title: Why role-playing games can spur climate action
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01466-x

Solving problems in a safe, collaborative environment can help us think out of the box and build empathy — crucial skills in a warming world.
item.dc:title: Why role-playing games can spur climate action
item.dc:creator: Sam Illingworth

item.title: Designer porous solids open up vast sandbox for materials research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01358-0

A simple design approach and predictive computational methods have spawned a pathway for making materials that could trap specific molecules — an ability needed for applications such as carbon capture.
item.dc:title: Designer porous solids open up vast sandbox for materials research
item.dc:creator: Dejan-Krešimir Bučar

item.title: Time’s restless ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01407-8

A qualified success.
item.dc:title: Time’s restless ocean
item.dc:creator: Jacey Bedford

item.title: AI networks reveal how flies find a mate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01320-0

Artificial neural networks that model the visual system of a male fruit fly can accurately predict the insect’s behaviour in response to seeing a potential mate — paving the way for the building of more complex models of brain circuits.
item.dc:title: AI networks reveal how flies find a mate
item.dc:creator: Pavan Ramdya

item.title: Element from the periodic table’s far reaches coaxed into elusive compound
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01480-z

Chemists achieve synthetic feat with radioactive promethium for the first time.
item.dc:title: Element from the periodic table’s far reaches coaxed into elusive compound
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: Promethium bound: fundamental chemistry of an elusive element finally observed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01193-3

The chemistry of promethium, a rare radioactive element, has been clouded in mystery, owing to its scarcity and the difficulties involved in working with it. The synthesis of a complex of promethium plugs this knowledge gap.
item.dc:title: Promethium bound: fundamental chemistry of an elusive element finally observed
item.dc:creator: Kristina O. Kvashnina

item.title: Cells cope with altered chromosome numbers by enhancing protein breakdown
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01360-6

When chromosomes are lost or gained, massive changes in gene expression disrupt the delicate balance of proteins in a cell. Yeasts with incorrect chromosome numbers counteract this by degrading excess proteins.
item.dc:title: Cells cope with altered chromosome numbers by enhancing protein breakdown
item.dc:creator: Zuzana Storchová

item.title: Protests over Israel-Hamas war have torn US universities apart: what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01492-9

Nature talks to researchers studying the protests about a high-stakes congressional hearing this week and accusations of antisemitism on campus.
item.dc:title: Protests over Israel-Hamas war have torn US universities apart: what’s next?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Singapore Airlines turbulence: why climate change is making flights rougher
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01542-2

Warming temperatures are likely to mean that more of your plane ride will have rocky conditions, creating potentially dangerous situations.
item.dc:title: Singapore Airlines turbulence: why climate change is making flights rougher
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: How the same brain cells can represent both the perception and memory of faces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01511-9

Long-term memories are thought to be represented by the same brain areas as those that encode sensory stimuli, but the mechanisms remain unclear. A study that recorded neural activity from face-selective regions of the macaque brain found that these regions represent familiar faces using a neural code that is distinct from the one for sensory representation.
item.dc:title: How the same brain cells can represent both the perception and memory of faces

item.title: China’s ChatGPT: what a boom in Chinese chatbots means for AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01495-6

ChatGLM is one of hundreds of AI language models being developed for the Chinese language. It comes close to ChatGPT on many measures, say its creators.
item.dc:title: China’s ChatGPT: what a boom in Chinese chatbots means for AI
item.dc:creator: Celeste Biever

item.title: Egypt is building a $1-billion mega-museum. Will it bring Egyptology home?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01467-w

For 100 years, Egypt’s scientists have watched as their nation’s story was largely told by institutions from Europe and the United States. Can a stunning new museum change that narrative?
item.dc:title: Egypt is building a $1-billion mega-museum. Will it bring Egyptology home?
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time

Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01489-4

Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time
item.dc:title: Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time
item.dc:creator: Linxiao Zhang

item.title: Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01491-w

Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.dc:title: Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Ewbank

item.title: Mars rover mission will use pioneering nuclear power source
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01487-6

The radioactive unit will help to deliver Europe’s first Mars rover to the planet’s surface.
item.dc:title: Mars rover mission will use pioneering nuclear power source
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01488-5

Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.dc:title: Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.dc:creator: Michael A. Spikes

item.title: Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01490-x

Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.dc:title: Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.dc:creator: Shoumit Dey
Pooja Sharma

item.title: Save the forest to save the tiger — why vegetation conservation matters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01368-y

The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, emphasizes the importance of conserving wild plant species, plus a wonderstruck sky-watcher spots a brilliant meteor, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Save the forest to save the tiger — why vegetation conservation matters

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: How psychology and neuroscience crack open the AI ‘black box’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01538-y

Researchers are borrowing approaches from psychology and neuroscience to find out how large language models ‘think’. Plus, self-driving super lab finds record-breaking laser material and AI-designed drugs get a reality check.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: How psychology and neuroscience crack open the AI ‘black box’
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Pay researchers to spot errors in published papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01465-y

Borrowing the idea of ‘bug bounties’ from the technology industry could provide a systematic way to detect and correct the errors that litter the scientific literature.
item.dc:title: Pay researchers to spot errors in published papers
item.dc:creator: Malte Elson

item.title: First ‘bilingual’ brain-reading device decodes Spanish and English words
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01451-4

Artificial-intelligence system allows a man who cannot speak coherently to have a conversation in the language of his choice.
item.dc:title: First ‘bilingual’ brain-reading device decodes Spanish and English words
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Lab-grown sperm and eggs: ‘epigenetic’ reset in human cells paves the way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01404-x

Technique wipes away tags on DNA that must be reprogrammed during development of reproductive cells.
item.dc:title: Lab-grown sperm and eggs: ‘epigenetic’ reset in human cells paves the way
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Harassment of scientists is surging — institutions aren’t sure how to help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01468-9

As researchers increasingly face many kinds of attack over their work, there is debate about how to support and protect them.
item.dc:title: Harassment of scientists is surging — institutions aren’t sure how to help
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: A global pandemic treaty is in sight: don’t scupper it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01464-z

Millions of people died of COVID-19 because the fundamental principle of equity between nations was ignored during the outbreak. That must not be allowed to happen again.
item.dc:title: A global pandemic treaty is in sight: don’t scupper it

item.title: Dumping, pillaging and slavery — why exploitation of the high seas must end
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01469-8

It’s time to sustainably manage the international ocean for marine and human life, says bold investigative book.
item.dc:title: Dumping, pillaging and slavery — why exploitation of the high seas must end
item.dc:creator: Diva Amon
Juliano Palacios Abrantes

item.title: Brazil’s plummeting graduate enrolments hint at declining interest in academic science careers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01504-8

The total number of individuals entering master’s and doctoral programmes dropped 12% between 2019 and 2022, reaching the lowest level in nearly a decade.
item.dc:title: Brazil’s plummeting graduate enrolments hint at declining interest in academic science careers
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo de Oliveira Andrade

item.title: How my research is putting blue crab on the menu in Croatia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01475-w

Neven Iveša investigates the invasive species in the Adriatic Sea, and works out how to lessen its impact.

item.title: The origin of the cockroach: how a notorious pest conquered the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01454-1

Genomic analysis suggests the common kitchen vermin spread from Europe to the world. But it wasn’t originally found in Europe.
item.dc:title: The origin of the cockroach: how a notorious pest conquered the world
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: How to set up your new lab space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01479-6

An empty room can be intimidating. But with some thoughtful planning, you can create a thriving scientific community.
item.dc:title: How to set up your new lab space
item.dc:creator: Marissa Coppola
Jessica W. Tsai

item.title: China's Yangtze fish-rescue plan is a failure, study says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01444-3

Researchers have debated the best management plan for highly endangered fish species since the 1980s.
item.dc:title: China's Yangtze fish-rescue plan is a failure, study says
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Why the European Space Agency should join the US mission to Uranus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01470-1

Without international partnerships, NASA’s groundbreaking mission could fail to be ready in time for its optimal launch window.
item.dc:title: Why the European Space Agency should join the US mission to Uranus
item.dc:creator: Olivier Mousis
Robin M. Canup

item.title: Daily briefing: We must get to Uranus by 2050 — and Europe can help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01497-4

How the European Space Agency can help boost a US mission to Uranus. Also, dams are hobbling ambitious conservation efforts for the Yangtze River and lessons from the first pig-organ transplants into humans.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: We must get to Uranus by 2050 — and Europe can help
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How religious scientists balance work and faith
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01471-0

Researchers find ways to interweave faith and science, from discussing Ramadan fasts with colleagues to applying religious parables to lab work.
item.dc:title: How religious scientists balance work and faith
item.dc:creator: Anne Marie Conlon
